summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell, detailing the production of discovery materials. The production includes search warrant returns and data from numerous electronic devices, including an iPhone seized from Jeffrey Epstein at the time of his 2019 arrest.

connections.description: Implicitly connected as the case against Maxwell is related to activities involving Epstein, and discovery includes data from his seized phone.
Everdell is listed as defense counsel receiving discovery for Maxwell's case.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Law enforcement seized an iPhone from Jeffrey Epstein at the time of his arrest.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: A protective order was issued in the case, governing the handling of confidential discovery materials.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The Government produced an initial batch of responsive materials from seized electronic devices to the defense.

events.title: Completion of Responsiveness Review
events.description: The Government completed its responsiveness review of images from Jeffrey Epstein's iPhone due to prior technical difficulties.

events.title: Supplemental Discovery Production
events.description: The Government produced additional discovery materials, including the final portion of images from Epstein's iPhone and other device data.

keyFacts: The document is a discovery production letter in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330).
The production includes data from an iPhone (Subject Device-2) seized from Jeffrey Epstein at the time of his 2019 arrest.
A total of 62 subject devices were searched pursuant to warrants, with a detailed chart provided showing which had responsive material produced.
The materials are governed by a protective order dated July 31, 2020, and much of the produced material is designated as confidential.
The letter reveals the ongoing and extensive nature of the digital evidence collection in the case, with productions occurring on November 9 and November 18, 2020.
